results.content:
This is my second Rails course that Jordan has taught, however this isn't a Rails course. It's in the title and description but there's absolutely zero teaching for Rails, it's all scaffolds and "here's the docs, read these" it's not worth any time or money if you want to learn Rails.

I highly recommend his other Rails courses but not this once. Additionally, the Angular is very out of date but you do learn the basics of what Angular can do.
results.content_html:

I highly recommend his other Rails courses but not this once. Additionally, the Angular is very out of date but you do learn the basics of what Angular can do.

results.content:
- Quite a few strange/bad practices like puting business logic in views instead of creating a method, not separating stuff in components(basic angular premisse), etc .
- The course feels more like a tutorial to angular. A superficial one, and if you are new to the framework I'm afraid you'll be probably confused. 
- Lots of time wasted talking about bootstrap. There's plenty of great bootstrap courses around and the subject should not take a entire module in a angular/rails course.
results.content_html:
- Quite a few strange/bad practices like puting business logic in views instead of creating a method, not separating stuff in components(basic angular premisse), etc .
- The course feels more like a tutorial to angular. A superficial one, and if you are new to the framework I'm afraid you'll be probably confused.
- Lots of time wasted talking about bootstrap. There's plenty of great bootstrap courses around and the subject should not take a entire module in a angular/rails course.

Thank you.

results.content:
The voice is monotonous and boring. I was shown how to install Homebrew package manager. The teacher prefers to use Homebrew. I found installing the Linux version (Linuxbrew) on Ubuntu combersome. In spite of this, the material covered is relevant. The link to the Angular quickstart does not work per the video explanation anymore, so it's great that he listed his github to get the source. 

I love the dynamic text editing in real time. I like the teacher also took the time to explain the planning and setup + many details. It is a tough pill to swallow, but I am glad the teacher put the planning stages in the course material first.
results.content_html:

results.content: I came to this course as a rails developer, and wanted a course that showed me how a microservice or api-only rails application would communicate with Javascript Frontend applications, like those done in Angular. Main reason being that I'd only worked on applications that were purely done in rails in the past, with the frontend handled in ERB and HAML. This course gave me exactly what I wanted to know in an in-depth and engaging way. It was my first Udemy course and I think I struck gold with this one!
results.content_html: I came to this course as a rails developer, and wanted a course that showed me how a microservice or api-only rails application would communicate with Javascript Frontend applications, like those done in Angular. Main reason being that I'd only worked on applications that were purely done in rails in the past, with the frontend handled in ERB and HAML. This course gave me exactly what I wanted to know in an in-depth and engaging way. It was my first Udemy course and I think I struck gold with this one!

I just finished going through the course. It was a little bumpy at the beginning because of changes to Angular 4 and version dependencies but once I got it running I had no issues following along at all with the course.

A word of advice to anyone having spacing issues with the card class in Bootstrap I suggest using md-3 inside you class call which solved the issue. Jordan did an outstanding job with the progression of the course is able to break down complex topics into easily digestible concepts.

results.content: This course really covers the basics on how to get a simple Rails API and call it from Angular2. It's a good base to get started. If you get stuck, there is usually enough info in the Q&A section to help you. Being a Rails developer, I wish the teacher would have spent more time explaining some of the code used in Angular. We end up typing some code without knowing exactly what it does, so how do we know whether we should use this in subsequent Angular2 projects is a mystery.
results.content_html: This course really covers the basics on how to get a simple Rails API and call it from Angular2. It's a good base to get started. If you get stuck, there is usually enough info in the Q&A section to help you. Being a Rails developer, I wish the teacher would have spent more time explaining some of the code used in Angular. We end up typing some code without knowing exactly what it does, so how do we know whether we should use this in subsequent Angular2 projects is a mystery.

results.content:
Excellent course. 
Jordan is an excellent instructor, highly skilled and knowledgeable on the topic. 
Course is easy to follow, and understand. 
I would only recommend to a host to update the Angular examples to the latest version, and maybe add authorization (Pundit or CanCanCan), and authentication (jwt, has_secure_token, devise_auth_token, etc). 
I was also expecting to see some file uploading gems such as Paperclip, and even better Shrine in action. 
But overall, this is a highly recommended course, and covers at least 85% of the things you'll ever need as a full-stack developer, and microservices.
results.content_html:
Excellent course.
Jordan is an excellent instructor, highly skilled and knowledgeable on the topic.
Course is easy to follow, and understand.
I would only recommend to a host to update the Angular examples to the latest version, and maybe add authorization (Pundit or CanCanCan), and authentication (jwt, has_secure_token, devise_auth_token, etc).
I was also expecting to see some file uploading gems such as Paperclip, and even better Shrine in action.
But overall, this is a highly recommended course, and covers at least 85% of the things you'll ever need as a full-stack developer, and microservices.

results.content: I am enjoying the course so far.  It is exactly what I was looking for.  Had a few issues on the difference in versions of some of the frameworks used in the course and what I have installed but the research required to resolve those issues have been a good learning experience.

results.content: Hard to work with old dependencies and troubleshooting issues from using angular2 + ngbootstrap4 when current standards have changed and technically ngbootstrap currently requires angular4+. It improved my knowledge of the setup by troubleshooting the errors caused by version issues (however I still have issues starting up the server after shutdowns). The additional resources that were provided by the instructor were wonderful and it felt like I got more than I paid for ($12)
results.content_html: Hard to work with old dependencies and troubleshooting issues from using angular2 + ngbootstrap4 when current standards have changed and technically ngbootstrap currently requires angular4+. It improved my knowledge of the setup by troubleshooting the errors caused by version issues (however I still have issues starting up the server after shutdowns). The additional resources that were provided by the instructor were wonderful and it felt like I got more than I paid for ($12)

results.content:
This is the second course I take with Jordan and I have always been very pleased with his teaching style. He explains material well and delivers upon expectations. 

I am not giving a full 5 stars because this is mostly an introduction to the interaction between angular and rails. Upon completion you will understand how to make the general HTTP request methods such as GET and POST. It was helpful for me as I was a bit clueless on how to connect backends with frontends, but I was hoping to see a few more topics that can really differentiate the course from yet another tutorial online. A suggestion would be to integrate omniauth authentication.

I do recommend this course as it is the best resource I have found to become closer to a true full-stack developer which consists on connecting backends with frontends.
results.content_html:
This is the second course I take with Jordan and I have always been very pleased with his teaching style. He explains material well and delivers upon expectations.

I am not giving a full 5 stars because this is mostly an introduction to the interaction between angular and rails. Upon completion you will understand how to make the general HTTP request methods such as GET and POST. It was helpful for me as I was a bit clueless on how to connect backends with frontends, but I was hoping to see a few more topics that can really differentiate the course from yet another tutorial online. A suggestion would be to integrate omniauth authentication.

I do recommend this course as it is the best resource I have found to become closer to a true full-stack developer which consists on connecting backends with frontends.

results.content:
Great course! It did get me through the Front-end Back-end communication barrier, and I feel strongly that this course will serve me well on my career. 

Jordan! I think it would be amazing if you'd include a bit of caching with Redis, I know it deviates a bit from the bigger picture of your course, but you'll find that there are no courses showing a simple integration between Redis and Rails, and I feel like it could be yet another big bump to this course :)

Thanks!
results.content_html:
Great course! It did get me through the Front-end Back-end communication barrier, and I feel strongly that this course will serve me well on my career.

Jordan! I think it would be amazing if you'd include a bit of caching with Redis, I know it deviates a bit from the bigger picture of your course, but you'll find that there are no courses showing a simple integration between Redis and Rails, and I feel like it could be yet another big bump to this course :)

Thanks!

results.content: A great exercise for illustrating the micro-service concept and for creating an Angular app for form generation and storage, utilizing two stand-alone Rails based APIs. I have done Jordan's "professional-rails-5-development-course" which is much more comprehensive and sets the bar high for what I look for in a Udemy course. If you are developing in Rails and curious about Angular integration (or the other way around), don't hesitate, do the course!
results.content_html: A great exercise for illustrating the micro-service concept and for creating an Angular app for form generation and storage, utilizing two stand-alone Rails based APIs. I have done Jordan's "professional-rails-5-development-course" which is much more comprehensive and sets the bar high for what I look for in a Udemy course. If you are developing in Rails and curious about Angular integration (or the other way around), don't hesitate, do the course!

results.content:
One of the most attractive feature of this course is that it integrates angular and rails to build one application. You can put the notion of Microservice application into practice with angular and rails. 
However you need to learn bunch of things outside of this course, if you are not familiar with any of these technologies, such as angular, typescript, rxjs, rails, bootstrap.
results.content_html:
One of the most attractive feature of this course is that it integrates angular and rails to build one application. You can put the notion of Microservice application into practice with angular and rails.
However you need to learn bunch of things outside of this course, if you are not familiar with any of these technologies, such as angular, typescript, rxjs, rails, bootstrap.

results.content: I really liked this course, I have never touched angular, now I can say that it is a interesting  and great framework and I think I am going to still practicing it, also I feel I have improved my dev skills and of course going to take more tutorials from Jordan Hudgens!

results.content: Just like other courses the instructor provides, this course is also very comprehensive and provides a very simple and good starting point for angular
results.content_html: Just like other courses the instructor provides, this course is also very comprehensive and provides a very simple and good starting point for angular

results.content: Great intro on micro services using Angular2 for frontend and Ruby on Rails as a backend API. Would love to see more tutorials like this, including how to authenticate users!
results.content_html: Great intro on micro services using Angular2 for frontend and Ruby on Rails as a backend API. Would love to see more tutorials like this, including how to authenticate users!

results.content: The course is precise and straight to the point however time is slowly catching up with it. It can be made better by updating it to more recent versions of Rails and Angular and also including some lessons for  modern tools like postman for API testing.
results.content_html: The course is precise and straight to the point however time is slowly catching up with it. It can be made better by updating it to more recent versions of Rails and Angular and also including some lessons for modern tools like postman for API testing.

results.content: Finished this course using Angular 7, Ruby 2.6.2, Rails 5.2.3 with everything working, had some struggles adjusting in section 46 and finishing that chapter with new Typescript syntax but nothing reading the documentation on the HTTPClient newer modules or moved modules couldn't fix. Great job Jordan going over the subject matter, walked away comfortable with Angular and a Rails backend API.
results.content_html: Finished this course using Angular 7, Ruby 2.6.2, Rails 5.2.3 with everything working, had some struggles adjusting in section 46 and finishing that chapter with new Typescript syntax but nothing reading the documentation on the HTTPClient newer modules or moved modules couldn't fix. Great job Jordan going over the subject matter, walked away comfortable with Angular and a Rails backend API.

results.content:
This course was a really valuable, interesting and engaging look at using Angular 2 with Rails 5.  It was somewhat challenging in places, but I found the end result really helped me understand how to better use the rails api feature and the value of microservice applications.  Great stuff Jordan, and all the best for 2017.

For people contemplating the course, I am a novice programmer with basic level understanding of Rails and Javascript.

results.content: I've signed up for this course to learn more on how to build a Rails API. It turned out the main topic was Angular 2. Never the less I learned quite a bit about Angular 2 and Typescript. It would be really nice if there are a few lectures explaining how to do authentication, authorization, caching and querying in  an API only application. Unfortunately there aren't many resources on the web going in details on the subject.
results.content_html: I've signed up for this course to learn more on how to build a Rails API. It turned out the main topic was Angular 2. It would be really nice if there are a few lectures explaining how to do authentication, authorization, caching and querying in an API only application. results.content:
This is the best tutorial ever :)  The only one that will show you how to use AngularJS the right way from A to Z.

It's very good, however, the angularJs documentation changed since the tutorial was created, and it's no longer possible to get the package.json, tsconfig.json and systemjs.config.js files from there.  For all else, it's a good course everyone who want to learn about AngularJS and Rails should enroll!
results.content_html:

results.content:
Jordan is solid instructor with a clear command over the subject matter, Rails and Angular2. In the course you get to build a cool/fun app that has potential to be customized into pretty much whatever you want. He keeps a decent pace, while making sure to spend extra time on topics that need a more in-depth explanation.

The number one take-away from this course for me, is that I NEVER want to work on anything involving Angular2... It's the worst! If this rating was for Angular2, I'd give it a -5 stars.

Just to end a positive note, Jordan does a great job in this course. If you're looking to learn how to incorporate Angular2 into your Rails app, this course will help you.
results.content_html:
Jordan is solid instructor with a clear command over the subject matter, Rails and Angular2. In the course you get to build a cool/fun app that has potential to be customized into pretty much whatever you want. He keeps a decent pace, while making sure to spend extra time on topics that need a more in-depth explanation.

The number one take-away from this course for me, is that I NEVER want to work on anything involving Angular2... It's the worst! If this rating was for Angular2, I'd give it a -5 stars.

Just to end a positive note, Jordan does a great job in this course. If you're looking to learn how to incorporate Angular2 into your Rails app, this course will help you.

results.content:
Mr. Hudgens is one of the best instructors I have seen around the internet. And believe me, I have taken classes from multiple sites and watched lots of youtube videos, on all sorts of topics. He has such a deep understanding of what each component of the programming language does, that you not only learn how to program real-world apps, you also learn the why's and how's of everything that is going on. Always a pleasure to learn from him. And as a bonus, he usually replies to whatever question, no matter how small, within 24 hours, sometimes within minutes. Depending on what time you submit the question.
I can't wait to see what other courses he comes out with. Thanks

results.content:
I like how this course encompasses an entire project from start to finish. The instructor is incredible at explaining fully what and why things are done. I like this guy's teaching style.  I will be taking more courses from him.

The only thing I would like to see is authentication.  This course leaves your backends completely wide open. It would be nice to have touched on this.

Overall this course taught me what I needed to get started.  It was a very thorough introduction to Angular2, as well as a good intro on how to set up the services needed to talk to Rails.  I'm very pleased.

I would love to see a followup  course that includes securing the server and how to properly deploy this application.
results.content_html:

The only thing I would like to see is authentication. This course leaves your backends completely wide open. It would be nice to have touched on this.

Overall this course taught me what I needed to get started. It was a very thorough introduction to Angular2, as well as a good intro on how to set up the services needed to talk to Rails. I'm very pleased.

I would love to see a followup course that includes securing the server and how to properly deploy this application.

results.content: I wanted to get some understanding of how Angular apps communicate with Rails APIs and that's exactly what I got. I learned a lot from this course. The instructor is great. If you already have worked with Angular, Rails, and Bootstrap it will be relatively easy to follow. Otherwise you should get familiar with the tools and then take this course. Just as advertised they use Angular 2 which is outdated, and Rails 5.
results.content_html: I wanted to get some understanding of how Angular apps communicate with Rails APIs and that's exactly what I got. I learned a lot from this course. The instructor is great. If you already have worked with Angular, Rails, and Bootstrap it will be relatively easy to follow. Otherwise you should get familiar with the tools and then take this course. Just as advertised they use Angular 2 which is outdated, and Rails 5.

results.content: Great course! Was exactly what I was after. Jordan went through the material at a nice pace, getting into some of the details when necessary but not getting too bogged down with the finer details. There were a few times where I had to stop the lecture or go back over some of the material, but they were few and far between.
results.content_html: Great course! Was exactly what I was after. Jordan went through the material at a nice pace, getting into some of the details when necessary but not getting too bogged down with the finer details. There were a few times where I had to stop the lecture or go back over some of the material, but they were few and far between.

results.content: This course is more an overview on how to build Angular 2 applications and integrate them with Rails, don't expect much details about the implementations and Angular core concepts, the instructor talk about them but in a very superficial way. In my opinion, that's OK, if you are just looking for a quick overview on angular 2. You also must have a medium knowledge on Ruby on Rails, because the instructor talks almost nothing about it.
results.content_html: This course is more an overview on how to build Angular 2 applications and integrate them with Rails, don't expect much details about the implementations and Angular core concepts, the instructor talk about them but in a very superficial way. In my opinion, that's OK, if you are just looking for a quick overview on angular 2. You also must have a medium knowledge on Ruby on Rails, because the instructor talks almost nothing about it.

results.content:
I've only recently started to use rails and as a real world project to help learn I've recreated my companies Employee Database originally hand coded in PHP. Rails is the first framework I have used and have never been a fan of JavaScript. I've been able to follow most of the javascript code I've come across however it is still foreign I've never used TypeScript nor Angular. In fact I haven't even heard of Angular until about 6 weeks ago when I purchased my first rails course.

With that being said, Jordan took time to explain the concepts behind micro services vs a monolithic approach and the pros and cons of each. He also took some very complex subjects such as observable's and made them understandable to new developers. Of course just like any type of schooling you get what you put in. While his course was helpful in a very broad sense of the word I had read up on observable's and the reactive type programming to better understand the concept and totally agree that they could be brought into their own mini course.

As far as the applications developed in this course I'm glad that we built the angular side first and Jordan explained really well the reason why structures were made a certain way at the time of development. In fact I'd say it was a little over explained :)  but it got the point across design your application to be scale-able with the least amount of changes possible. I'd love to see more courses to build on this application adopting authentication where the developer and the client email used during setup can view the proposal however restricting access from other freelancers seeing others projects/clients/pricing to try and underbid them. Also hiding other clients from the perspective client so they don't feel like they are over paying if the price/hour is different.

I am looking to play around more with angular and rails API's and possibly building out my employee database again using this type of structure. The reason I think it would benefit from this type of application is I've found that when we have multiple people in the office working in the database they might be working on the same thing and seeing updates in real time will help prevent double work.

I'd also like to implement (even for this project) an digital signing system I've seen there are a few for Angular and I'll have to research them some more but i think those would be maybe a fun little extra project (bonus content).

Jordan again this is the first time I've taken a course you've taught and believe me when I say I will be taking more. I've learned a lot and have enjoyed myself in the process. So much so that my fiance has threatened to wear the Angular and Rails emblems as a costume so I'd watch a movie with her :) Ok all jokes aside thanks a million for this course and I'm looking forward to more.
results.content_html:

As far as the applications developed in this course I'm glad that we built the angular side first and Jordan explained really well the reason why structures were made a certain way at the time of development. I'd love to see more courses to build on this application adopting authentication where the developer and the client email used during setup can view the proposal however restricting access from other freelancers seeing others projects/clients/pricing to try and underbid them. Also hiding other clients from the perspective client so they don't feel like they are over paying if the price/hour is different.

I am looking to play around more with angular and rails API's and possibly building out my employee database again using this type of structure. The reason I think it would benefit from this type of application is I've found that when we have multiple people in the office working in the database they might be working on the same thing and seeing updates in real time will help prevent double work.

I'd also like to implement (even for this project) an digital signing system I've seen there are a few for Angular and I'll have to research them some more but i think those would be maybe a fun little extra project (bonus content).

results.content:
As usual and as always expected from Jordan, The course material is great, and the in depth explanations were great as well.

I'm just kinda disappointed at the end of it because it wasn't what i have just expected when i enrolled in this course.

What i was really expecting and waiting for is to see a real world application is being made, it doesn't have to be a real application but there is another functions which i was aim to have them explained but there were not.

Like Association between model on Rails and how can i have Association between 2 micro services and how to simulate the login (Authentication system) on a micro service.

But overall this is another great course just to get started on basic Angular on Rails app, I don't think you can do advanced apps without have some more material to learn.

But once again, Thanks Jordan for this, You're always an inspiration to me

results.content: This is more like a "tutorial". You will learn "how to" do things. TypeScript and Rails are required skills as prerequisites. Anyway, Jordan explains all topics with great detail and clarity.
results.content_html: This is more like a "tutorial". You will learn "how to" do things. TypeScript and Rails are required skills as prerequisites. Anyway, Jordan explains all topics with great detail and clarity.

results.content:
Great course! Its mainly focused on Angular 2, what was great for me since I already have some experience with rails. I missed a few things like talking about directives, and communication between components, but with what I learned here I'm now able to learn the rest through some other tutorials.
Instructor is excellent, it's the second course I took with him and I would take a third  :)
results.content_html:
Great course! Its mainly focused on Angular 2, what was great for me since I already have some experience with rails. I missed a few things like talking about directives, and communication between components, but with what I learned here I'm now able to learn the rest through some other tutorials.
Instructor is excellent, it's the second course I took with him and I would take a third :)

results.content:
This course is excellent and covers exactly what I wanted to see from an Angular frontend/Rails backend course.

A few topics that I would love to see added:
- Implementing PUT/DELETE in our API as well as updating/deleting records in our frontend.
- Authentication. Authenticating to our backend and letting the frontend know that the user is authenticated. One example that I would like to see is conditionally formatting the links in the nav bar based on whether or not the user is logged in.
results.content_html:

results.content: If you are somewhat familiar with Rails and interested in learning Angular, this is definitely one of the best tutorials out there. Jordan explains every single action he does in a way that most instructors don't take the time to do. He also explains Angular in a way that is relatable from a Rails point-of-view. I would HIGHLY recommend this course to any who fits the description I described above.
results.content_html: If you are somewhat familiar with Rails and interested in learning Angular, this is definitely one of the best tutorials out there. Jordan explains every single action he does in a way that most instructors don't take the time to do. He also explains Angular in a way that is relatable from a Rails point-of-view. I would HIGHLY recommend this course to any who fits the description I described above.

results.content: This course cover minimum knowledge how to use Angular2 with Rails (that is great). Everything is very simple and easy to learn. Some parts need update to new version of rxjs but in this case you can always search on google and learn more (but it will be good to update to new version)
